Comments_Questions: How clearly did the instructor define the topic of study
How clearly did the instructor outline the expectation for the course, classroom activity and homework
How well were individual class sessions prepared and presented
How well did lectures fit within the boundaries of the course
How available was the instructor for help outside the classroom
How useful were assignments in furthering an understanding of the topic
If tests were given, how fairly did they measure knowledge gained?
How useful was this course in preparing you for production work
How would you evaluate the instructor's knowledge of the material
Please offer additional comments on such topics as: what worked best about the course, suggested improvements, class materials, etc.
Comments_List: The scope of this class was succinctly elucidated.
He wrote the book...
End of semester homework due dates were a little unclear, but other than that very clear.
extremely well.
Knew what and when things were due and at least what day Exams would be held.
Very well prepared. A little dry in presentation, but so much good information.
it is hard to imagine someone else teaching this class and being this well prepared.
Followed the book...
I understand that there is a lot of information to cover but it made days difficult when class went over time.
Fit within the boundaries but were sometimes more difficult to interpret than the book.
Heavy but fair
for what we were learning, very appropriate.
There were some ruff times... I mean really dark, soul crushing, melancholy lit by the midnight oil kind times doing homework during production assignments... but the 2 week policy was very helpful.
I spend too much time on this.... Only the future will let me know if this was good or not.
Jenna was sometimes available, but we knew that Ben was mostly retired so it was not even thought of to ask to see him outside of class.
The TA especially did an awesome job of being available for questions and scheduling extra review sessions before tests.
TA was available.
Not sure the repetition in some chapter assignments is really necessary.
Tests were good, but the marathon nature makes it also about how well you can stay in it. Are there ways shorter tests could be figured out?

Many of the structures questions are a test of what you didn't learn but use the easy part of what you did learn. They're intentionally tricky but to the detriment of learning, as there's an element or multiple pieces of each test that are not taught nor in the book but are knowledge of math that one should have entered the program with. Which is unfortunate for those who have struggled with or not had math of this level in a long time.
in the future, absolutely, but as a first year, not really.
I have not had a technical direction assignment yet so I have not had the opportunity to directly apply it to production work here.
Not sure at this time.
I haven't have the chance or need to run structures for any of my productions.
Literally wrote the book...
this question is laughable in reference to Ben Sammler.
He literally wrote the book.

I would have wanted some class in the shop where we could do some testing and practice working. By this, my learning would have been reached not only by classes/lecturs inputs, but also by testing "I Hear and I Forget, I See and I Remember, I Do and I Understand"
